{% extends "layout.html" %} {% block title %} Stone skipping {% endblock %} {% block content %} {% filter markdown %} ## Your new hobby is: # Stone skipping Stone skipping and stone skimming are considered related but distinct activities: both refer to the art of throwing a flat stone across the water in such a way (usually sidearm) that it bounces off the surface. The objective of "skipping" is to see how many times a stone can bounce before it sinks into the water; the objective of "skimming" is to see how far a bouncing stone can travel across the water before it sinks into the water. In Japan, the practice is referred to as Mizu Kiri , which loosely translates to "water cutting." In Mizu Kiri contests, both skimming and skipping principles, as well as a throw's overall aesthetic quality, are taken into account to determine the winners. Find out more on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone skipping)! {% endfilter %} {% endblock %}
